questions.question_text: A WAN technician reviews activity and identifies newly installed hardware that is causing outages over an eight-hour period. Which of the following should be considered FIRST?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Network performance baselines 
 if the device configuration is wrong at first place you will know it BUT it took eight-hour period although Device configuration review is easier to check ,In summary, while checking device configurations can be relatively easy due to accessibility and directness, it may not always be the most effective first step in troubleshooting network outages caused by newly installed hardware. Understanding network performance baselines provides context that enhances the effectiveness of any subsequent configuration reviews.

comments.content: wrong im sorry D is the right answer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If having outages after installing new hardware. If you have options for checking performance baselines, or the configuration review document first, it will be faster to check the configuration review first. Configuration review identifies the weaknesses, threats and vulnerabilities in the network devices and resources, by allocating the threat rating to each of the configuration so that appropriate controls may be applied to reach the higher level of security.
https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/importance-configuration-review-graxoconsulting#:~:text=Configuration%20review%20identifies%20the%20weaknesses,the%20higher%20level%20of%20security.

Selected Answer: D
D. Device configuration review

Reviewing the configuration of the newly installed hardware is crucial to identify any misconfigurations or conflicts that might be causing the outages. This includes checking the device settings, interfaces, IP addresses, routing configurations, and any other relevant parameters. By examining the device configuration, the technician can pinpoint issues related to the new hardware that may be impacting network performance.

While network performance baselines, VLAN assignments, and routing tables are important considerations, they come into play after the initial review of the device configuration to further investigate and optimize the network. The immediate focus is on the configuration of the newly installed hardware causing the outages.

Selected Answer: D
When a WAN technician identifies newly installed hardware causing outages, the FIRST consideration should be D. Device configuration review.

Reviewing the configuration of the newly installed hardware will help identify any misconfigurations, conflicts, or errors that might be causing the outages. By examining the settings and setup of the hardware, the technician can pinpoint any discrepancies that could lead to network disruptions and address them accordingly.

Once the configuration review is completed and any issues are resolved, subsequent steps such as checking network performance baselines, VLAN assignments, and routing tables can be taken to ensure the smooth operation of the WAN.

Selected Answer: D
The answer is D for device config review.

The keyword here is hardware being reviewed, he will be checking devices alone first before troubleshooting anything else.

Selected Answer: C
Layer 3 switches are equipped with the necessary intelligence to run dynamic routing protocols such as OSPF (Open Shortest Path First), RIP (Routing Information Protocol), or EIGRP (Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol). They can make decisions on how to forward packets based on the information gathered from these dynamic routing protocols.
Layer 3 Hub

questions.question_text: Which of the following would enable a network technician to implement dynamic routing?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Gateway is the correct answer.

XX.XX.4.1 and XX.XX.4.30 will still be in the subnet when the mask is set to 255.255.255.224 (/27)

comments.content: to add to this you can see that the gateway is xx.24.xx.xx as opposed to the IPs being on xx.26.xx.xx

And some of claim that the user can use /27 subnet mask, yes, that can be happened but check the question. It states "The network engineer observes that all users have lost Internet connectivity.". All peer's IP configuration is fine with /27 but it can't explain why all users have lost their internet connections.

That is because the range 196.26.4.0 - 196.26.4.31 which is in /27 is also in the range of 192.168.4.0/26 (which is 192.168.4.0 - 192.168.4.63). When the subnet mask is applied it will think the gateway is directly connected and will send the arp request to the gateway if the gateway was set correct.
The question says 196.26.4.0/26 not 196.26.4.0/27. Therefore, the Subnet Mask is wrong and it won´t work as the /26 was given by the ISP and it can´t be modified.
Totally agree with you. The Subnet mask is wrong, they need be 255.255.255.192 for /26
I corrected myself, the gateway configuration is incorrect.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Incorrect Subnet Mask was configured. The correct subnet mask is 255.255.255.192

comments.content: Incorrect. You can use /27 even though ISP gave you a /26. The gateway however is not in the network at all

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The issue here is with the subnet mask which should be .192 for /26 and not .224 which is for /27.

Selected Answer: A
The ISP assigned 196.26.4.0/26, which means the subnet mask should be 255.255.255.192. This subnet mask gives an IP range from 196.26.4.0 to 196.26.4.63.
However, the configuration on the interface shows a subnet mask of 255.255.255.224, which corresponds to a /27 subnet. This subnet mask provides an IP range from 196.26.4.0 to 196.26.4.31.

Selected Answer: A
The issue likely lies in the configuration of the subnet mask. The IP range 196.26.4.0/26 has a subnet mask of 255.255.255.192, which allows for 64 IP addresses (62 usable for hosts). If the subnet mask is incorrectly configured, it can cause connectivity issues.

Here are some potential problems to check:

Incorrect Subnet Mask: Ensure that the subnet mask is set to 255.255.255.192 on all devices.
Incorrect Gateway Configuration: Verify that the gateway IP address is correctly set within the assigned range.
IP Address Conflicts: Check for any IP address conflicts within the network.

Selected Answer: A
Incorrect Subnet is answer
/26 means 8.8.8.11000000
255.255.255.192
also /26 gives 64 ip address. ISP and client ip are within the 64 Range

Incorrect Subnet is answer
/26 means 8.8.8.11000000
 255.255.255.192
also /26 gives 64 ip address. ISP and client ip are within the 64 Range

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. The incorrect gateway was configured.

The gateway IP address should be within the same subnet as the IP address of the interface. The subnet for the IP address 196.26.4.30 with subnet mask 255.255.255.224 (/26) is 196.26.4.0 to 196.26.4.63. However, the configured gateway IP address 196.24.4.1 is not within this range. Therefore, the gateway IP address is incorrect and needs to be reconfigured to an IP within the 196.26.4.0/26 subnet.

comments.content: did you just study this to pass? or did you also do self studying to get that high of a score?

discussion.content:
I took the exam last week (on March 21, 2024) and I answered A (incorrect subnet mask). I scored 861/900. 

It is not answer B (incorrect gateway), because the gateway mentioned in the question was: 196.26.4.1

Selected Answer: B
The gateway router's interface configuration includes the following information:

IP address: 196.26.4.30
Subnet mask: 255.255.255.224
Gateway: 196.24.4.1
The subnet mask 255.255.255.224 corresponds to a /27 subnet, not a /26 subnet. Therefore, the correct subnet mask for the assigned IP range 196.26.4.0/26 should be 255.255.255.192, not 255.255.255.224. This misconfiguration prevents the gateway router from properly communicating with devices outside the local network, causing all users to lose Internet connectivity.

Selected Answer: B
Clearly, the gateway is not in the ISP-provided subnet range

both the gateway and the subnet mask are incorrect. However, the issue that directly impacts the loss of Internet connectivity for all users is the incorrect gateway configuration.Even if the subnet mask were correct, without the correct gateway, the traffic wouldn't be routed properly to reach the internet. So, while both are issues, the incorrect gateway configuration more accurately describes the immediate cause of the loss of connectivity. Therefore, option B, the incorrect gateway configuration, best describes the issue.

Selected Answer: B
/30 would be ".252" not "224". Subnet Mask Is Incorrect. Google and take a look at the CIDR notation sheet

Selected Answer: B
I typed whole question and image into BING AI:

The issue is with the gateway that was configured. The gateway IP address should be within the same subnet as the IP address of the interface. In this case, the IP address of the interface is 196.26.4.30 and it falls within the 196.26.4.0/26 subnet. However, the gateway IP address 196.24.4.1 does not fall within this subnet. Therefore, the correct answer is B. The incorrect gateway was configured. The gateway should be an IP address from the 196.26.4.0/26 subnet.

Selected Answer: B
Gateway, second octet is different

Selected Answer: B
Both an incorrect subnet mask and an incorrect default gateway can cause loss of Internet connectivity. However, given the information provided:

- The subnet mask is set to 255.255.255.224, but it should be 255.255.255.192 for a /26 network. This incorrect subnet mask could cause issues with routing and connectivity within the local network.
- The gateway IP address is set to 196.24.4.1, which is not in the same subnet as the IP address of the interface (196.26.4.30). This could prevent the router from correctly routing traffic to and from the Internet.

It's hard to definitively say which is the "main" cause without more information, as both could potentially lead to a loss of Internet connectivity. However, typically, an incorrect default gateway would more directly lead to a loss of Internet connectivity, as the default gateway is responsible for routing traffic between the local network and the Internet. So if forced to choose one, I would lean towards **B. The incorrect gateway was configured** as being the main cause.

comments.content: This is an excellent explanation, thank you very much.

Really is not an incorrect subnet, because you can use VLSM and you can have an address, with /27 after you have a /26 came from the ISP, but if you look the gateway IP address. 196.24.4.1 and the network address is 196.26.4.0 so the gateway is in a different network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Going with gateway for now. I'm guessing that for this question, even if the subnet mask was incorrect like it is here, it wouldn't really explain the loss of internet connectivity for all users. The /26 subnet assigned by the ISP would mean that the router should use 255.255.255.192 as the subnet and not 255.255.255.224 since it's /27. The incorrect subnet should lead to some routing issues between the router and the ISP, but you might still can get internet connectivity depending on the ISP. An incorrect gateway would flat out stop all internet connectivity since the traffic would have no way to being properly routed.

This could just be a typo with the gateway since another comment mentioned that the test had updated the gateway to be a valid IP. If that's the case I'd go with subnet, but for now sticking with gateway.

discussion.content: /26 cidr gives a subnet mask of 255.255.255.192. The subnet mask is incorrect 100%. Ive done and passed this exam multiple times, know your subnetting and CIDR!

Selected Answer: A
- The issue is with the subnet mask being used on the gateway router. The subnet mask 255.255.255.224 is not consistent with the IP range assigned by the ISP (196.26.4.0/26).
- A /26 subnet mask is 255.255.255.192, not 255.255.255.224. This means that the subnet mask on the gateway router is incorrect and the gateway router may be sending traffic intended for the Internet to the incorrect network.
- Note: The gateway of 196.24.4.1 is not the branch gateway it's the ISP gateway which connects the branch to other networks (i.e. the Internet)

Selected Answer: B
Two things are wrong with this one, /26 should be .192 and the GW address is 192.24 instead of 192.26. Reading the question, the incorrect gateway is the most correct answer.

Answer A is right.
In the question, the branch switched to the new ISP, and ISP provides 196.26.4.0/26 which is basically 255.255.255.192 not 255.255.255.224(196.26.4.0/27). So branch has old router gateway it only switched to the new ISP you don't have to configure the gateway as it comes to the 2nd option, what you have to configure is new ip address with subnet mask first.

Selected Answer: A
This question is weird.

FIRST: the Gateway is the interface (i.e Serial 0/0/0 in routing configuration) connecting the ISP and the company router to the assign network 196.26.4.0. So the network for that interface between them 196.24.4.0.
SECOND: The IP of the interface to the company network is x.x.x.30, it should be x.x.x.1 because its the gateway of the assigned network. Its common practice to give the first host IP to the gateway but i guess they picked 30 instead for this.

The Gateway in the configuration is just the network that the ISP and the company router is in. The interface (being improperly assigned) is okay. All in all, that leaves the network mask being incorrect as the correct answer.

An interesting trick question. While the ISP assigned 196.26.4.0/26, it doesn't mean the user has to use all the IP ranges. In this case, the given assignable IP range is 196.26.4.1 to 196.26.4.62. The user chose to use CIDR of 27 instead of 26 which give assignable IP range of 196.26.4.1 to 196.26.4.30 which evidently within the given range.

The gateway on other hand is 196.24.4.1, a completely different subnet. So B is the answer.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be BEST suited for a long cable run with a 40Gbps bandwidth?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
CAT 8 = 40GBASE-T - 40Gbps - 30 Meters. Distance the cable can go can be improved through a repeater.

Selected Answer: D
For a long cable run with a 40Gbps bandwidth, the BEST option would be Cat 8 cable. Cat 8 is designed to support up to 40Gbps over a distance of up to 30 meters, making it the most suitable option for long cable runs with high bandwidth requirements.
Cat7 has more range @ 50M? Not C?
D IS THE ONE

Selected Answer: D
Only Cat 8 is capable of 40Gbit at all. Not over very long distances, though, 30m max…

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.
Media convertor indeed
it says "cost effective" which is more cost effective, a GBIC connector or a media converter?

Selected Answer: A
Media converter converts fiber to copper connections
A use a media convertor

choices.D: Use a loopback adapter to make the connection
choices.C: Change the type of connector from SC to F-type
choices.B: Install an additional transceiver module and use GBICs
choices.A: Use a media converter and a UTP cable

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a valid and cost-effective solution to connect a fiber cable into a network switch without available SFP ports?
